database_info.name: Personalized Health Biomarker and SNP Database
database_info.description: Comprehensive database of blood biomarkers and genetic SNPs for personalized health applications

low.description: Low vitamin D levels may indicate insufficient sun exposure, poor dietary intake, malabsorption, kidney or liver disease, or certain medications. Can lead to bone weakness, increased infection risk, fatigue, and mood disorders.
lifestyle_recommendations: Spend time outdoors during peak sunlight hours
supplement_recommendations: Calcium if dietary intake is low

high.description: High vitamin D levels are rare but can occur from excessive supplementation. May cause hypercalcemia, kidney stones, nausea, vomiting, and kidney damage.
supplement_recommendations: Consider magnesium to help regulate calcium

low.description: Very low CRP levels are generally good, indicating minimal inflammation in the body. This is associated with lower cardiovascular disease risk.

high.description: Elevated CRP indicates systemic inflammation, which may be due to infection, autoimmune conditions, cardiovascular disease, or chronic inflammatory conditions. Increases risk of heart disease and stroke.

low.description: Very low homocysteine levels are generally beneficial, indicating good methylation function and low cardiovascular risk.
lifestyle_recommendations: Continue balanced diet with adequate protein

high.description: Elevated homocysteine increases risk of cardiovascular disease, stroke, blood clots, and cognitive decline. May indicate B-vitamin deficiencies, kidney disease, or genetic variants affecting methylation.

low.description: B12 deficiency can cause fatigue, weakness, memory problems, depression, nerve damage, and megaloblastic anemia. Common in vegetarians, elderly, and those with absorption issues.
lifestyle_recommendations: Include B12-rich foods (meat, fish, dairy, eggs)
supplement_recommendations: Consider B12 injections if severe deficiency

high.description: Very high B12 levels may indicate liver disease, kidney disease, or certain blood disorders. Generally not harmful from supplements alone.
supplement_recommendations: Continue other B vitamins as needed

low.description: Low ferritin indicates iron deficiency, which can cause fatigue, weakness, pale skin, brittle nails, restless leg syndrome, and decreased exercise tolerance.
lifestyle_recommendations: Include iron-rich foods (red meat, poultry, fish)
Combine iron with vitamin C foods
Address any sources of blood loss
supplement_recommendations: Consider lactoferrin for gentle iron support

high.description: High ferritin may indicate iron overload, inflammation, liver disease, or hemochromatosis. Can increase oxidative stress and disease risk.
lifestyle_recommendations: Avoid vitamin C supplements with meals

low.description: Low TSH may indicate hyperthyroidism, causing symptoms like rapid heartbeat, weight loss, anxiety, heat intolerance, and tremors.

high.description: High TSH indicates hypothyroidism, causing fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, depression, dry skin, and hair loss.

low.description: Very low cholesterol may indicate malnutrition, liver disease, hyperthyroidism, or certain medications. Can affect hormone production and cell membrane function.

high.description: High cholesterol increases risk of cardiovascular disease, stroke, and atherosclerosis. May be due to diet, genetics, or underlying conditions.

low.description: Very low LDL is generally beneficial for cardiovascular health, though extremely low levels may affect hormone production.

high.description: High LDL cholesterol is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease and atherosclerosis. Contributes to plaque buildup in arteries.

low.description: Low HDL cholesterol reduces the body's ability to remove excess cholesterol, increasing cardiovascular disease risk.
lifestyle_recommendations: Include healthy fats (olive oil, nuts, avocado)

high.description: Very high HDL is generally protective against cardiovascular disease, though extremely high levels may indicate other health issues.

low.description: Very low triglycerides are generally beneficial, indicating good metabolic health and low cardiovascular risk.

high.description: High triglycerides increase risk of cardiovascular disease, pancreatitis, and metabolic syndrome. Often associated with insulin resistance.

low.description: Low fasting glucose may indicate hypoglycemia, which can cause dizziness, weakness, confusion, and fainting. May be due to medications, liver disease, or hormonal imbalances.

high.description: High fasting glucose indicates prediabetes or diabetes, increasing risk of cardiovascular disease, kidney damage, nerve damage, and other complications.

low.description: Very low HbA1c may indicate hypoglycemia, anemia, or certain blood disorders. Generally indicates good glucose control.

high.description: High HbA1c indicates poor glucose control over 2-3 months, increasing risk of diabetes complications including cardiovascular disease, kidney damage, and neuropathy.

low.description: Low insulin may indicate type 1 diabetes, pancreatic insufficiency, or hypopituitarism. Can lead to hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis.

high.description: High insulin indicates insulin resistance, increasing risk of type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, and cardiovascular disease.

low.description: Very low ALT is generally not concerning and may indicate good liver health.

high.description: Elevated ALT indicates liver cell damage or inflammation, possibly due to fatty liver, hepatitis, medications, or alcohol use.

low.description: Very low AST is generally not concerning and indicates good liver and muscle health.

high.description: Elevated AST may indicate liver damage, muscle damage, heart problems, or other tissue damage. Can be due to exercise, medications, or disease.

low.description: Low GGT is generally beneficial and indicates good liver health and low oxidative stress.

high.description: Elevated GGT indicates liver stress, oxidative damage, or bile duct problems. Often elevated with alcohol use, fatty liver, or medications.

low.description: Very low bilirubin may indicate reduced antioxidant capacity, as bilirubin has protective antioxidant properties.

high.description: High bilirubin may indicate liver dysfunction, bile duct obstruction, hemolysis, or Gilbert's syndrome. Can cause jaundice.

low.description: Low albumin may indicate liver disease, kidney disease, malnutrition, inflammation, or protein loss. Can cause edema and poor wound healing.

high.description: High albumin may indicate dehydration or hemoconcentration. Generally not concerning if mild elevation.

low.description: Low creatinine may indicate low muscle mass, malnutrition, or liver disease. Generally not concerning unless extremely low.

high.description: High creatinine indicates reduced kidney function, which can be due to kidney disease, dehydration, medications, or muscle breakdown.
lifestyle_recommendations: Limit protein intake if kidney disease

low.description: Low BUN may indicate liver disease, malnutrition, overhydration, or low protein intake.

high.description: High BUN may indicate kidney dysfunction, dehydration, high protein intake, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

low.description: Low eGFR indicates reduced kidney function, which can progress to chronic kidney disease and increase cardiovascular risk.

high.description: High eGFR is generally good, indicating excellent kidney function, though extremely high values may indicate hyperfiltration.

low.description: Very low uric acid may indicate Wilson's disease, Fanconi syndrome, or certain medications. Uric acid has antioxidant properties.

high.description: High uric acid increases risk of gout, kidney stones, and cardiovascular disease. May be due to diet, genetics, or kidney dysfunction.

low.description: Low calcium may indicate vitamin D deficiency, parathyroid disorders, kidney disease, or malabsorption. Can cause muscle cramps, numbness, and bone problems.

high.description: High calcium may indicate hyperparathyroidism, excessive supplementation, certain cancers, or granulomatous diseases. Can cause kidney stones and cardiovascular problems.

low.description: Low magnesium can cause muscle cramps, fatigue, irregular heartbeat, anxiety, and increased risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes.
lifestyle_recommendations: Include magnesium-rich foods (nuts, seeds, leafy greens)
supplement_recommendations: Take with food to reduce GI upset

high.description: High magnesium is rare but can occur with excessive supplementation or kidney disease. May cause diarrhea, nausea, and muscle weakness.

low.description: Low phosphorus may indicate malnutrition, vitamin D deficiency, hyperparathyroidism, or certain medications. Can cause bone pain and weakness.

high.description: High phosphorus may indicate kidney disease, hyperparathyroidism, or excessive intake. Can cause calcium-phosphorus imbalance and cardiovascular problems.
lifestyle_recommendations: Limit phosphorus-rich foods if kidney disease
Reduce processed foods (high in phosphorus additives)

low.description: Low sodium (hyponatremia) can cause confusion, seizures, muscle cramps, and swelling. May be due to excessive water intake, medications, or hormonal imbalances.
supplement_recommendations: Sodium chloride as directed by physician

high.description: High sodium (hypernatremia) can cause thirst, confusion, and seizures. Usually due to dehydration or excessive sodium intake.

low.description: Low potassium can cause muscle weakness, fatigue, irregular heartbeat, and increased blood pressure. May be due to medications, diarrhea, or inadequate intake.
supplement_recommendations: Potassium citrate 99mg daily (prescription for higher doses)
Avoid potassium chloride supplements without supervision

high.description: High potassium can cause dangerous heart rhythm abnormalities. May be due to kidney disease, medications, or excessive supplementation.
supplement_recommendations: Calcium and sodium as directed by physician

low.description: Low chloride may indicate metabolic alkalosis, excessive sweating, vomiting, or certain medications.

high.description: High chloride may indicate dehydration, kidney disease, or metabolic acidosis.

low.description: Low CO2 may indicate metabolic acidosis, kidney disease, or respiratory compensation for acidosis.

high.description: High CO2 may indicate metabolic alkalosis, respiratory acidosis, or compensation for respiratory issues.

low.description: Low anion gap may indicate hypoalbuminemia, multiple myeloma, or laboratory error.

high.description: High anion gap may indicate metabolic acidosis, kidney disease, diabetes, or toxin exposure.

low.description: Low total protein may indicate malnutrition, liver disease, kidney disease, or protein loss.

high.description: High total protein may indicate dehydration, chronic inflammation, or certain blood disorders.

low.description: Low globulin may indicate immunodeficiency, liver disease, or malnutrition.

high.description: High globulin may indicate chronic inflammation, autoimmune disease, or certain infections.

low.description: Low A/G ratio may indicate liver disease, kidney disease, or autoimmune conditions with high globulin levels.

high.description: High A/G ratio may indicate immunodeficiency or low globulin production.

low.description: Low white blood cell count may indicate immune suppression, bone marrow disorders, autoimmune conditions, or certain medications.
lifestyle_recommendations: Support immune system with adequate sleep

high.description: High white blood cell count may indicate infection, inflammation, stress, or blood disorders.

low.description: Low red blood cell count (anemia) can cause fatigue, weakness, pale skin, and shortness of breath.
lifestyle_recommendations: Address any sources of blood loss

high.description: High red blood cell count may indicate dehydration, lung disease, kidney disease, or polycythemia.

low.description: Low hemoglobin indicates anemia, causing fatigue, weakness, and reduced oxygen delivery to tissues.
lifestyle_recommendations: Address underlying causes of blood loss

high.description: High hemoglobin may indicate dehydration, lung disease, or polycythemia, increasing blood viscosity.
supplement_recommendations: Omega-3 fatty acids for blood flow

low.description: Low hematocrit indicates anemia or blood loss, reducing oxygen-carrying capacity.

high.description: High hematocrit may indicate dehydration or polycythemia, increasing stroke and clot risk.

low.description: Low MCV indicates microcytic anemia, often due to iron deficiency or thalassemia.

high.description: High MCV indicates macrocytic anemia, often due to B12 or folate deficiency, or alcohol use.

low.description: Low MCH indicates iron deficiency or other causes of microcytic anemia.
lifestyle_recommendations: Enhance iron absorption with vitamin C

high.description: High MCH may indicate B12 or folate deficiency, or macrocytic anemia.

low.description: Low MCHC indicates hypochromic anemia, often due to iron deficiency.

high.description: High MCHC may indicate spherocytosis, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, or laboratory error.

low.description: Low RDW indicates uniform red blood cell size, which is generally normal.

high.description: High RDW indicates variable red blood cell sizes, suggesting nutritional deficiencies or blood disorders.

low.description: Low platelet count (thrombocytopenia) increases bleeding risk and may indicate bone marrow disorders, autoimmune conditions, or medications.

high.description: High platelet count (thrombocytosis) may increase clotting risk and could indicate inflammation, cancer, or blood disorders.

low.description: Low MPV may indicate bone marrow disorders or certain medications affecting platelet production.

high.description: High MPV may indicate increased platelet turnover, inflammation, or cardiovascular risk.

low.description: Very low ESR is generally good, indicating minimal inflammation.

high.description: High ESR indicates inflammation, infection, autoimmune disease, or cancer.

low.description: Low testosterone can cause fatigue, decreased muscle mass, low libido, depression, and bone loss.

high.description: High testosterone may indicate PCOS in women, steroid use, or certain tumors.
supplement_recommendations: Saw palmetto (for men with high DHT)

low.description: Low free testosterone indicates bioavailable testosterone deficiency, affecting energy, muscle, and sexual function.

high.description: High free testosterone may indicate hormonal imbalances or external hormone use.

low.description: Low estradiol can cause hot flashes, mood changes, bone loss, and cardiovascular issues, especially in women.

high.description: High estradiol may increase risk of blood clots, breast cancer, and other estrogen-related conditions.

low.description: Low progesterone can cause irregular periods, mood swings, sleep issues, and fertility problems.

high.description: High progesterone may cause drowsiness, mood changes, and breast tenderness.

low.description: Low DHEA-S may indicate adrenal insufficiency, chronic stress, or aging, leading to fatigue and reduced stress resilience.

high.description: High DHEA-S may indicate adrenal hyperplasia, PCOS, or excessive supplementation.
supplement_recommendations: Spearmint tea for women with PCOS

low.description: Low morning cortisol may indicate adrenal insufficiency, causing fatigue, weakness, and poor stress response.

high.description: High morning cortisol may indicate chronic stress, Cushing's syndrome, or poor sleep, leading to various health issues.

low.description: Low IGF-1 may indicate growth hormone deficiency, malnutrition, or liver disease, affecting muscle growth and repair.

high.description: High IGF-1 may increase cancer risk and indicate acromegaly or excessive growth hormone.

low.description: Low leptin may indicate low body fat, malnutrition, or leptin deficiency, leading to increased appetite.

high.description: High leptin indicates leptin resistance, often associated with obesity and metabolic dysfunction.

low.description: Low adiponectin is associated with insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and increased cardiovascular risk.

high.description: High adiponectin is generally protective against metabolic disease and cardiovascular risk.

low.description: Low vitamin A can cause night blindness, dry eyes, poor immune function, and skin problems.
lifestyle_recommendations: Include vitamin A rich foods (liver, carrots, sweet potatoes)

high.description: High vitamin A can be toxic, causing liver damage, bone problems, and birth defects.
lifestyle_recommendations: Reduce vitamin A rich foods temporarily
supplement_recommendations: Avoid multivitamins with high vitamin A

low.description: Low vitamin E can cause muscle weakness, vision problems, and immune dysfunction.
lifestyle_recommendations: Include nuts, seeds, and vegetable oils

high.description: Very high vitamin E may increase bleeding risk and interfere with vitamin K.

low.description: Low vitamin K can cause bleeding disorders and poor bone health.

high.description: High vitamin K may interfere with blood thinning medications.

low.description: Low folate can cause megaloblastic anemia, fatigue, and increased homocysteine.
supplement_recommendations: Avoid synthetic folic acid if MTHFR variant

high.description: Very high folate may mask B12 deficiency and affect immune function.

low.description: Low thiamine can cause fatigue, confusion, muscle weakness, and cardiovascular problems.

high.description: High thiamine is generally safe but may indicate excessive supplementation.

low.description: Low Vitamin C (Ascorbic Acid) levels may indicate deficiency, malabsorption, or underlying health conditions.

high.description: High Vitamin C (Ascorbic Acid) levels may indicate excess intake, supplementation, or metabolic dysfunction.

low.description: Low Biotin (B7) levels may indicate deficiency, malabsorption, or underlying health conditions.

high.description: High Biotin (B7) levels may indicate excess intake, supplementation, or metabolic dysfunction.

low.description: Low Pantothenic Acid (B5) levels may indicate deficiency, malabsorption, or underlying health conditions.

high.description: High Pantothenic Acid (B5) levels may indicate excess intake, supplementation, or metabolic dysfunction.

high.description: High Riboflavin (B2) levels may indicate excess intake, supplementation, or metabolic dysfunction.

high.description: High Niacin (B3) levels may indicate excess intake, supplementation, or metabolic dysfunction.

high.description: High Pyridoxine (B6) levels may indicate excess intake, supplementation, or metabolic dysfunction.

high.description: High Copper levels may indicate excess intake, supplementation, or metabolic dysfunction.

variants.effect: Normal MTHFR enzyme function, efficient folate metabolism
dietary_recommendations: Balanced diet with adequate B vitamins

variants.effect: Moderately reduced MTHFR enzyme activity (about 65% of normal)
dietary_recommendations: High folate foods (dark leafy greens, asparagus, broccoli)
Limit processed foods and refined sugars
Avoid fortified foods with synthetic folic acid

variants.effect: Significantly reduced MTHFR enzyme activity (about 30% of normal)
lifestyle_recommendations: Avoid medications that interfere with folate
dietary_recommendations: Very high folate diet (multiple servings of leafy greens daily)
Organic foods to avoid synthetic folic acid

snps.name: COMT Val158Met
snps.impact: Dopamine metabolism, stress response, cognitive function

variants.effect: Fast COMT enzyme activity, rapid dopamine clearance (Warrior type)
Intermediate COMT enzyme activity, moderate dopamine clearance
lifestyle_recommendations: Balanced approach to stress and relaxation

variants.effect: Slow COMT enzyme activity, slow dopamine clearance (Worrier type)
Fast caffeine metabolizer, efficient CYP1A2 enzyme activity
lifestyle_recommendations: Can consume coffee throughout the day

variants.effect: Intermediate caffeine metabolism, moderate CYP1A2 activity
Slow caffeine metabolizer, reduced CYP1A2 enzyme activity
lifestyle_recommendations: Monitor for anxiety and sleep issues
Increased cardiovascular risk with high caffeine
dietary_recommendations: Avoid energy drinks and caffeine pills

snps.name: APOE
snps.impact: Alzheimer's disease risk, cardiovascular health, lipid metabolism

variants.effect: Protective against Alzheimer's disease, may have higher triglycerides
Lower Alzheimer's risk, generally favorable lipid profile
Average Alzheimer's risk, typical lipid metabolism
Increased Alzheimer's risk (3-4x), higher cardiovascular risk
Highest Alzheimer's risk (10-15x), significant cardiovascular risk
supplement_recommendations: Very high-dose omega-3 fatty acids 3-4g daily

snps.name: DAO (AOC1)
snps.impact: Histamine metabolism, food sensitivities, allergic reactions

variants.effect: Normal DAO enzyme function, efficient histamine breakdown
dietary_recommendations: Balanced diet including all food groups

variants.effect: Moderately reduced DAO enzyme activity, some histamine sensitivity
dietary_recommendations: Limit aged cheeses and cured meats

variants.effect: Significantly reduced DAO enzyme activity, high histamine intolerance risk
dietary_recommendations: Avoid aged, fermented, and processed foods
supplement_recommendations: DAO enzyme supplements before every meal

snps.name: BDNF Val66Met
snps.impact: Brain neuroplasticity, learning, memory, mood regulation

variants.effect: Normal BDNF function and secretion, optimal neuroplasticity
Moderately reduced BDNF secretion, some learning/memory impact
Significantly reduced BDNF secretion, impaired neuroplasticity
lifestyle_recommendations: Intensive cognitive training and brain exercises
Daily aerobic exercise (critical for BDNF production)

snps.name: VDR Taq1
snps.impact: Vitamin D receptor function, calcium absorption, immune function

variants.effect: Normal vitamin D receptor function, efficient vitamin D utilization
Moderately reduced vitamin D receptor sensitivity
lifestyle_recommendations: Regular monitoring of vitamin D levels

variants.effect: Significantly reduced vitamin D receptor function
dietary_recommendations: Limit foods that inhibit calcium absorption

snps.name: MAOA
snps.impact: Serotonin and dopamine metabolism, mood regulation, aggression

variants.effect: High MAOA enzyme activity, efficient neurotransmitter breakdown
Intermediate MAOA enzyme activity, moderate neurotransmitter metabolism
Low MAOA enzyme activity, slower neurotransmitter breakdown
Normal MTHFR enzyme function at A1298C position
Moderately reduced MTHFR enzyme activity, affects neurotransmitter synthesis
Significantly reduced MTHFR enzyme activity, major impact on neurotransmitters
Normal CBS enzyme function, efficient sulfur metabolism
dietary_recommendations: Include sulfur-rich foods (garlic, onions, cruciferous vegetables)

variants.effect: Moderately upregulated CBS enzyme, faster sulfur processing
Significantly upregulated CBS enzyme, very fast sulfur processing

snps.impact: Glutathione S-transferase activity, detoxification, oxidative stress
